scenario_0.summary: During peak inbound and outbound operations, Worker 1 and Worker 2 both frequently travel back and forth along the G-row corridor between Area 5 (G19) and the Waste Area (G3), as well as Areas 1–2, for sorting, inspection, staging, and disposal tasks. Worker 1 receives and inspects new stock in Area 5, then moves between Area 5, Areas 1–2, and the Waste Area, while Worker 2 clears Areas 1–2, transfers items to large shelves, and also transports defective goods to the Waste Area. Their workflows overlap extensively, often causing both workers (and their carts or pallets) to pause, maneuver, or temporarily block the G-row corridor at unpredictable intervals. As the robot follows its fixed path from G19 to G3, it is repeatedly forced to stop, wait, or slow down because its route coincides with the busiest shared operational corridor, resulting in the longest possible total time for the robot to complete its route due to frequent worker-caused obstructions.

scenario_1.summary: During a simultaneous quarterly inventory audit and emergency product recall, Worker 1 conducts sequential item recounts across all Large Shelves, moving misplaced or surplus items to Area 1 or 2, while Worker 2 retrieves recalled items from Shelves, Boxes, and Areas 1/2, transporting them to Area 5 for sorting and then to the Waste Area. Both use the G-row corridor intensively: Worker 1 repeatedly crosses the main aisle to stage or collect items, often pausing mid-corridor to annotate or sort, while Worker 2 regularly moves bulky retrieved goods between Area 5 and the Waste Area, placing trolleys and objects along the route. High activity and frequent unsynchronized crossovers create persistent, unpredictable obstructions as both workers temporarily block or occupy the fixed robot pathway at multiple points. The robot, navigating autonomously from G19 to G3, is forced to stop or slow repeatedly due to worker presence and ad hoc item placement, resulting in maximally extended total travel time, all arising from legitimate, operationally necessary warehouse activities without intentional interference.

scenario_2.summary: During a simultaneous warehouse capacity rebalancing and urgent dispatch event, Worker 1 continuously moves pallets and overflow inventory from Boxes 3 and Large Shelf 2 into Areas 1 and 2, frequently pausing with pallets or partially unloading in the G-row corridor (columns 6–15) for restaging and documentation. Meanwhile, Worker 2 picks urgent items from Shelves 5–6, Boxes 1, and Large Shelf 3, shuttling trolleys loaded with dispatch parcels from G19 leftward to Areas 5 and 4, making frequent mid-corridor stops to prepare packages, attach labels, and gather packing materials. Both workers commonly use or block the central G-row simultaneously and independently, often leaving trolleys and pallets in the aisle or pausing at key waypoints, creating dynamic, unpredictable, and multi-point obstructions along nearly the entire fixed robot route. The robot, traveling from G19 to G3, is forced to repeatedly stop or slow for long periods wherever worker activity or temporary blockages occur, maximizing its total time to complete the route. This scenario’s persistent, overlapping, independent high-priority workflows naturally generate the highest possible indirect disruption to the robot’s path due to dense, shifting worker presence and corridor congestion.

scenario_3.summary: During a mandatory 'Quality Blitz Day,' Worker 1 (Quality Inspector) and Worker 2 (Material Handler & Waste Segregator) operate interleaved, high-overlap cycles involving frequent item inspections, staging, and mass disposal. Worker 1 inspects items in Area 5, shuttles suspect goods to Area 2 for recheck, and moves confirmed waste to the Waste Area, repeatedly traveling left and right along the G-row corridor, often pausing with carts adjacent to the robot’s route. Worker 2 hauls new stock from Large Shelf 4 to Area 5 and simultaneously ferries waste bins from the Waste Area to Large Shelf 1, frequently crossing and blocking waypoints along the G-row (G19–G3) as he pauses to reorganize loads or coordinate with Worker 1. Their activities, including staging, re-sorting, and bin handling, lead to repeated, unpredictable physical blockages along every major waypoint of the robot's fixed pathway, requiring the robot to stop, wait, or slow at multiple stages, and producing the slowest-possible completion time for the robot’s task—all due to legitimate, unsynchronized human workflows and not intentional disruption.

scenario_4.summary: An urgent hazardous materials misclassification crisis triggers a warehouse-wide emergency recertification sweep. Worker 1 (Recertification Specialist) shuttles potentially noncompliant items from all Large Shelves and Area 5 to staging zones in Areas 3 and 4 for detailed compliance checks, unpacking and sorting each box on-site. Worker 2 (Hazardous Materials Handler) synchronously collects identified hazardous items from the inspection zones, transporting them to the Waste Area or, if further review is needed, back to Area 5 or Boxes 2–3. Both workers repeatedly cycle through and pause in the critical G-row corridor, staging items, repositioning trolleys, and conducting task hand-offs in tight spaces. Their overlapping, highly dynamic inspection and waste transport workflows—combined with frequent, legitimate stoppages, repackaging, and mutual zone congestion—create near-continuous, unpredictable obstructions directly along the robot’s fixed route (G19→G3). The robot, which can only react to environmental changes and must navigate around static or moving blockages, experiences the maximum possible delays, stopping or slowing at every segment due to legitimate workflow congestion as both workers perform high-frequency, compliance-driven item handoffs, repackaging, and transport in and out of Areas 3, 4, 5, Waste, and adjacent corridors.

scenario_5.summary: During a full-system workflow validation and stress-testing operation, Worker 1 is assigned to move returned or older stock from Large Shelves 2 and 3 to Area 2 for compliance check, sort items for reintegration into central Shelves or disposal, and shuttle all waste leftward to the Waste Area, often staging bins along the G-row corridor. In parallel, Worker 2 rapidly cycles between bulk pick (Boxes 1/2), central Shelves, and dispatch staging (Area 5), assembling mixed orders, pausing to sort, label, or replenish, and repeatedly crossing the G-row corridor and staging containers at corridor intersections. Both workers frequently double-back, pause for checks, and stage bins or trolleys in the central aisle, resulting in constant, unpredictable, and extended blockages at nearly every segment of the robot's fixed G19→G3 path. The combined effect of dense, overlapping, and unsynchronized traffic—plus frequent temporary static obstacles—forces the robot to slow, stop, or detour repeatedly, thus taking the longest possible total time to reach its waste-dumping goal, with all process delays emerging naturally from the operational demands of simultaneous high-frequency pick, return, compliance, and dispatch flows.

scenario_6.summary: During a simultaneous urgent cross-docking operation and a facility-wide defective goods quarantine audit, Worker 1 rapidly shuttles inbound stock from Boxes 1–3 and Large Shelf 1 to Area 1 for immediate sorting, then splits outgoing product to central Shelves 3/5 and recalls rejected goods back to staging. At the same time, Worker 2 audits all outgoing and staging items for defects, transporting suspected goods from Area 5, Shelves 2/4, and staging zones to the Waste Area, frequently consolidating or pausing in Areas 3 and 4 for inspection and quarantine. Both workers make repeated use of trolleys and carts, often staging them or pausing to document, sort, or inspect directly within the G-row corridor (G19–G3), which is also the robot’s only route. The unpredictable, persistent mix of cross-traffic, multi-area crossings, ad hoc object placement, and overlapping tasks creates dynamic, near-constant obstructions along the entire robot route. As a result, the robot must stop, wait, or frequently slow at almost every segment of its fixed path to the Waste Area, yielding the maximum possible completion time, with all delays arising from the legitimate, high-frequency, and unsynchronized operational activities of both workers.

scenario_7.summary: During an unscheduled, high-pressure product recall operation, Worker 1 (Returns Processor) continually shuttles recalled goods from Large Shelf 4 to Area 5 for inspection, then sorts items into Area 2 for possible restocking or takes irreparable stock to the Waste Area. Simultaneously, Worker 2 (Ad Hoc Restocker & Auditor) rapidly cycles between Shelves 1–6, Large Shelf 2, and Areas 1–2 to pull substitute goods for outbound orders, reloads valid returns from Area 2, and removes damaged items for disposal, all while staging and handling bulk loads via carts and bins. Their workflows overlap extensively: both workers frequently pause or stage bins, carts, and return loads directly along the main G-row corridor (waypoints G19–G3), often leaving objects in the aisle as they perform time-consuming checks, documentation, or recategorization. The robot, which must travel along G19 to G3, is repeatedly obstructed by both workers’ legitimate, time-intensive staging and processing activities at every critical point of its path, forcing it to stop, wait, or take detours throughout its entire route. There is no direct human-robot communication—delays arise solely from real operational overlap and workspace congestion, resulting in the maximally extended total time for the robot to reach its goal.

scenario_8.summary: During an end-of-quarter bulk consolidation and process redesign pilot, Worker 1 is tasked with collecting and moving overflow pallets from Large Shelf 1 and Large Shelf 4 into Areas 1, 2, and 5 for staging and audit, frequently transporting and unloading large loads directly along the main G-row corridor (G19–G3). Worker 2 leads an on-the-fly sortation pilot, circulating throughout Areas 1, 2, and 5 to inspect, sort, and relay goods for further storage, redeployment, or waste, repeatedly transferring bins and staging containers along the same G-row path before moving sorted waste to the Waste Area (G3). Both workers’ high-frequency, large-object movements, ad hoc corridor staging, and overlapping, interdependent workflows cause persistent, multi-point, and sometimes simultaneous obstructions across the robot’s entire fixed path from G19 to G3. The robot must constantly stop, wait, or detour due to these legitimate, operationally driven blockages—extending its total travel time to the maximum possible, all without any direct communication or intentional interference.

scenario_9.summary: During a quarterly deep replenishment and ongoing repack audit, Worker 1 (Deep Replenishment Worker) shuttles slow-moving items from Shelves 2/4 and operational Areas 2/4 to Large Shelves 1/3, while restocking picking Shelves from bulk Boxes 2/3. Worker 2 (Repack Audit Specialist) continuously audits and repacks goods from Area 5, Area 1, and operational Areas 3/4, relocating repacked or failed items to operational Areas or the Waste Area. Both workers use the G-row corridor for main transit and prolonged mid-task stops, setting up audit tables or staging overstock bins at random waypoints (e.g., G6, G8, G12, G14, G17, G18). Their independently scheduled, asynchronous workflows heavily overlap in the central aisle, with frequent pauses, bin/carts staging, and unpredictable retracing, creating persistent, dynamic environmental obstacles along the robot's fixed route from G19 to G3. As the robot traverses the G-row, it must repeatedly stop, wait, or detour in reaction to human-caused blockages, resulting in the scenario with the longest possible time to reach its goal through entirely legitimate, high-frequency warehouse processes, without any intentional interference or direct human-robot interaction.
Worker 1: G7 ↔ G8 ↔ G7 (Double-back at left corridor)
Boxes 2 → Area 1 (via corridor left; linger at G4)
G4 ↔ G5 ↔ G4 (Oscillation at corridor extreme)
Worker 2: G19 ↔ G18 ↔ G19 (Oscillate start corridor block)
G16 ↔ G17 ↔ G16 (Oscillate at right corridor)
G14 → Area 1 (move toward left, pause at G7)
G7 ↔ G8 ↔ G7 (Oscillation at left corridor)
